page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Transitive and Ditransitive
page.introduction: Some examples of English transitive single-clause sentences are:

EnglishExample.exItem: The batter will hit the ball.
The dog might have buried his bone.

form.instruction: Since Experiencer subjects are distinct from Agent subjects in your language, add the feature experiencer to the verbs which have an Experiencer subject.
If a verb is transitive and its object must always be present, add the feature transitive to its lexical entry. Do not mark a verb like eat which may or may not have an overt object.
form.introduction: Ditransitives can have the second object expressed as a prepositional or postpositional phrase or as a nominal phrase. Some languages, like English, allow both (via Dative Movement as in example 8 below). Some English examples of ditransitives are given below.

EnglishExample.exItem: The girl bought the present for her mother.
The man sold his car for two thousand dollars.
The girl gave the gift to her mother.
The girl gave her mother the gift.

radioGroup.prompt: What syntactic category is the second object in a ditransitive in your language?
radioGroup.radio: A prepositionalpostpositionalprepositional or postpositional phrase phrase only
As in English, either a nominal phrase or a prepositionalpostpositionalprepositional or postpositional phrase

radioGroup.prompt: When both objects are nominal phrases, which object appears closest to the verb?
radioGroup.radio: The direct object is next to the verb
The indirect object is next to the verb

form.instruction: Any verbs which require the second object to always be present should be marked with the feature ditransitive. Those which allow the second object, but it is optional, can be marked transitive.
